channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Summer is calling… Perl role in Malta
item.description: Perl programmers, your skills are in demand. Sure, you could keep slogging away in your current role, but maybe it’s time to try something — or somewhere — new. Consider Malta: azure waters, 300 days of sunshine per year, and a population widely known as some of the friendliest people in the world. Doesn’t that sound like the place you want to be?

item.title: Scrooge had it right! Perl role in Vienna
item.description: Our client is one of the largest product and price comparison platforms in German-speaking countries. They’re not saying you shouldn’t spend money, but if you’re going to splash out on the latest gear, why not get the best price? Client is willing to consider all candidates with strong Perl, but they make heavy use of PostgreSQL, Elasticsearch, and Modern Perl.

item.title: NLP is all right by me! Perl, Python, NLP role in Amsterdam
item.description: A global leader in machine intelligence matching job seekers with their perfect career: our client’s goal is human level parsing. They’re on the hunt for an NLP Engineer whose passion for NLP is matched only by their interest in Machine Intelligence and their ability to drive quality improvements, measurement standards, and error analysis processes for the NLP framework.

item.title: Forget the carrot and stick! Perl role in London
item.description: As a company at the top of their game, they are looking for a Perl developer who is similarly eager to be the best. You’ll thrive in an environment where you work independently and in teams, and you enjoy writing code with a variety of languages.

item.title: Wanted: Senior Perl developers with good karma. Remote Perl within US, UK, CH, SA and CAN
item.description: Our client is a multinational fundraising group that works with thousands of charities to provide cloud-based management tools, a dedicated social fundraising platform, and a secure channel for charities to receive funds. Looking for Modern Perl developers who have experience with automated payment systems.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
.

item.title: How deep is a recursion in Perl?
item.description: How can you find out the current depth of the recursion?

item.title: Weekly Challenge 123
item.description: Simon never beat the bush and always get to the point straight. He always write easy to read code. Keep up the great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 123: Ugly Square
item.description: Roger blog always made it obvious that he is well read geek. His reference point is always an eye opener for me. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 123
item.description: Luis showed his PDL knowledge and shared how he used PDL to solve the Square Points task. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 123: Ugly Numbers and Square Points
item.description: Laurent solution to Ugly Numbers is very impressive. Thank you for sharing your experience with us.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge #123
item.description: James have impressed me with his performance matrix. He is not scared of trying different approach to improve the performance. Keep up the great work.

item.title: TWC: Punting to MJD and Showing Q&D Geometry
item.description: I loved the JIT blogging section. Not sure if Jared comes from Java background. To me JIT belongs to Java. I respect the honesty with which he solved the Ugly Numbers task. Hats Off to him.

item.title: PWC123 - Square Points
item.description: Flavio touched the bit that I didn't even thought of when proposed the task. At times, I doubt my ability to analyze a task. I am learning every week from Flavio. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: PWC123 - Ugly Numbers
item.description: You can never be bored of reading blog by Flavio. I enjoy the most discussion of the task itself which then followed up with code. Keep up the great work.

item.title: Ugly and Square: Perl Weekly Challenge #123
item.description: Coding is a skill one can master with time but writing beautiful code is an art. Dave has mastered the art so well. Please checkout his blog.

item.title: Don’t Be an Ugly Square, Man
item.description: Colin's writings is elite as always. You can view it as pure literature material and technical blog also. I simply love it.

item.title: CY's Take on The Weekly Challenge #123 ‐ N-cube
item.description: It makes me proud to see the progress in Cheok-Yin. The quality of her blog is the proof. Highly Recommended.

item.title: Ugly Points with Raku and Perl
item.description: Thorough discussion of Square Points task is really worth reading. Appreciate the hard work it takes to create the blog.

item.title: Ugly Numbers / Square Points
item.description: Adam sharing his work in C++ and Prolog this week along with Perl. What a bonus, thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 123: Square Points
item.description: Abigail once again shared the mathematical angle of the Square Points task. He made it appear so simple and easy that even non-Mathematical brain would also understand. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 123: Ugly Numbers
item.description: Abigail shared very interesting facts about Ugly Numbers. You must check it out.

item.title: Perl Review - Perl Weekly Challenge - 121
item.description: Perl Solutions Review by Colin Crain.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 123
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Ugly Numbers" and "Square Numbers" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 124
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Happy Women Day" and "Tug of War". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: List of new CPAN distributions - Jul 2021
item.description: PERLANCAR is leading the list of new CPAN distributions in July 2021

item.title: Release 1.56 of perl-workflow, a bug fix release
Are you using Cache::Memcached and its ->stats method?
item.description: A module that is probably used by some large projects, but not maintained any more. Without a link to its public VCS, if it is even have a public VCS. Probably the best approach would be to reach out to the original author and the author of the most recent release via their email or social network profile.

item.title: Perl UV binding hits version 2.000
item.description: libuv is a cross-platform event handling library, which focuses on providing nicely portable abstractions for things like TCP sockets, timers, and sub-process management between UNIX, Windows and other platforms. UV is the Perl bindings for it.

item.title: Speaking at Developer Career Day 2021
item.description: Many people complain how perl has a bad reputation based on incorrect information outside of the Perl bubble. Very few do about it anything. Try blogging outside the bubble.

item.title: perlbrew improved
item.description: perlbrew to better name each build that is based on an arbitrary commit and not on a released version of Perl.

item.title: Zapp: Runbook Automation
item.description: I did not know what a runbook is, I guess it is something others call a checklist. What I do no is that I agree about the problems with Jenkins and I love to see something like this being developed. It can be an excellent tool for SREs and people whom are often called DevOps engineers. IMHO, in order to make it catch on it needs its own web-site that is not MetaCPAN. It needs to have an installation that does not require any knowledge of Perl. These are two big areas where others could help the project. Of course 'just' using it and reporting any issues would also be extremely valuable.

item.title: The Funhouse Mirror of Perl Criticism
item.description: An excellent writing about the tools you can use to improve the way you and your team writes Perl code. However, how can you make sure you don't break your code while you implement the changes recommended by these tools?

item.title: #523 - How to improve your Perl?
item.description:
Hi there!

There were not many posts this week, but some of them were really interesting.

Personally I got a bit overwhelmed with work. It is very interesting that there are organizations where people don't know how to use git properly, where they hardly have any tests and no CI is running, but they already have Kubernetes set up because some consultant thought that would be cool to use it.

On one hand it makes me angry that people don't introduce testing, CI, and CD early in the development process. It would be a lot cheaper, smoother and faster for them, but on the other hand I also like trying to figure out how thing happen to work. Sometimes, it seem, by total chance.

Enjoy your week!
